title: Core-T Printed Wheels All Axis Spectra Driven

description.text:
*Update 10-02-14
I'm having issues with the wheels on my z-axis. It's looking like there's just too much slop with all the weight on 3060 extrusion. The 3060 is not wide enough either, unless a more constrained bearing is used. Right now I'm going to put some effort into a couple different linear bearing designs at the same cost of the 608 bearings. The 608 wheels are viable, but there's too much room for variability. I'm going to play around with some zinc plated BBs or airsoft pellets. Update 09-23-14
Added design files for a MKII bed support that hooks to the z-axis carriage. It prints in two halves, with 4 extensions for the sides. The major issue though is the lever arm force on the bed. It's looking like I'm going to have to add another extrusion for stabilizing, or I'm going to have to utilize the front two extrusions in a "X" formation. Here's a test video of it: http://youtu.be/v4dTq7hZGCA. You can see how bad the wobble can be unfortunately.
Update 09-20-14
Added some new carriage designs, which eliminate the need for 5 mm screws. Gained some build volume. Still working on the build platform.
////////////
Update 09/14/14
I have redesigned the z-axis to be cable driven as opposed to screw driven. My threaded rod had way too much wobble. I will leave screw option for those interested. I still have to upload a modified z-axis carriage, I just drilled holes in the old one for the spectra line. Right now the cable driven axis seems promising. Granted there's no weight from the bed, but the motor won't have a problem when powered. It's similar to the belt driven z-axis mod I made for the Ord Bot. I'm using the motor bracket from SWFL3D: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15180. Just have to add the build platform now and extruder.
////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
I am ready to introduce a project of mine. I now call it the Core-T (I found the previous name taken by another robot). It utilizes CoreXY kinematics and is spectra line driven. The frame is 30 mm extrusion that can be bought at a lot of different sources. Uses printed wheels only and no linear bearings or rods! My main design goal was to avoid linear bearings as well as openbeam, v-slot, or makerslide. While those are nice, a complete wheel/bearing package is around $4 a piece. This overcomes that with inexpensive, widely available 608 bearings and inexpensive printed wheels. I'm using M8 socket cap screws to hold up the corexy pulleys. This makes them strong and free of flexing.
Right now the x and y axes are functional and pretty smooth. Here's a video of them running: http://youtu.be/1-CuOnObo3k. I originally modded the carriages for belts, but ran out of belts. That's why I switched to spectra. I will update the carriages for spectra line. I also need to shorten them up a little bit so I can maximize build volume. I'm going to be using Wild Bill's extruder for now, until I upgrade it to use a Makerbot type extruder.
Credit goes to LoialOtter for the initial design of the carriages: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:20659. Also I have to give credit to AndyCart for his spectra pulleys from his design: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:313048. Finally credit to capitaenz for the side guides for my spectra 608 pulleys: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:31216
Current frame volume is 350mm x 350 mm x 350 mm. Build volume is about 175 mm x 250 mm x 330 mm.

BOM:
Non-Printed Parts:
20 x 608 Bearings
24 M8x20mm Flat Socket Screws
8 x M8x20mm Socket Head Cap Screws
22 x M6x12mm Socket Cap Head Screws
8 x M8 30 Series T slot nuts
22 x M6 30 series T slot nuts
16 x 350 mm x 30 mm T slot
1 x 3060 T slot x 500 mm
16 x M4 x 14mm Socket head cap screws
12 x M5 x 25 mm Socket head cap scres
Printed Parts:
8XBearing spacer
2X cx_motor_bracket
2Xcbottom
1X extruder body
1X cexbh1
1Xcex-th2
1X z-axis bushing
4Xctop
32Xwheel-74
2Xcbottom-bar
1Xz-axis motor bracket
1 X cex-bh2
1X cex-th1
8XExtrusion_bracket
2Xdrive pulley
2Xz lift front
1X cz-lift2
1Xcz-lift1
1XWB Idler
16X side_guide
3Xendstop mount

comments.author: adamcooks

comments.text: I like the design.  I've been thinking of doing the same for a while.  Just curious if you've considered trying to counteract the falling z platform when the motor's not powered.  I had a theory of a pulley at top of frame and one at bottom, either end attached to the platform.  While by itself, the same situation would exist.  But add a gear on the bottom one, and then add a second set of pulley's, with it's own loop of spectra line,  with a gear of it's own interlocked with the first.  The gravity from the first set would turn the gear, thus turning the other gear the opposite way and reversing the force along that loop.  If tied to the platform would exert the opposite force and keeping it from falling.  Does my theory sound right?
comments.author: darrelhunt

comments.text: Hi darrelhunt,
comments.author: darrelhunt

comments.text: I wasn't necessarily thinking about the sag at the front of the bed rather than keeping the platform stationary when the motors are off.  I was thinking something like this.  sorry it's kind of crude, but should get the point across.  Both A and B would be connected to the platform.  Gravity should be translated through the gears and pulleys back to the bed to counteract itself.
comments.author: runninfarmer

comments.text: I just mentioned the sag, in case you wanted to try 3060 extrusions.  I think I get what your saying now, but I believe you'll wan't to connect your carriage at different places. If you do connect your carriage at A and B, the two pulleys will pull against each other and the carriage won't move at all. It won't even let your motor move it, since it would be working against itself.  But, if you fix A, you could put a connection at D, and then it would be good to go.  You could alternatively do B and C. I like your gearing connecting the bottom pulleys and that will add detent  torque to the pulley system. That extra detent torque, is what could keep the platform from falling when motor(s) unpowered. Here's a link to a pic with what I'm talking about:
comments.author: darrelhunt

comments.text: I see what you mean.  When I held points A and B together, they would not move.  Interesting though, I was browsing some Physics Forums and found a Patent (lapsed, useable) that might be a good implementation.

I made this model as a test rig for an ultrasonic bed leveling system.
This part is designed to mount an ultrasonic range finder to the fan on a stepstruder/MakerGear MkX direct drive extruder.
This is my first 3D model uploaded to Thingiverse. I may have to redesign it now that I think about it, as there is nowhere for the leads coming off of the pin headers to go.

My Prusa i3 had trouble printing the fan grill vertically, so I am working on a new design. The new version has an H-rail attached to one side of the fan grill, and the ultrasonic mount has a slot to slide onto the rail. These will be released soon. I decided to take the H-rail route to easily add other extruder mods (print cooling fan mount, extruder LED ring, webcam mount, etc)
This is my model for the extruder mod rail: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:466195 . I will convert the ultrasonic module soon.

These will clamp onto your Nema23 stepper motor to serve as a mounting point for a drag chain. The mounting holes suit 10x15 drag chain but can be easily reworked after printing to suit other sizes.  
The square clamp will suit most motors with a 56mmx56mm foot print. The chamfered clamp will mount onto the body areaas shown in the picture..

Just got my new Duplicator 4 and the plexiglass door was having issues staying closed during the print.  So I designed this magnetic door stop and added the magnet to the stop and the door to hold it closed.  I have included the DWG file so that you have the opportunity to change the magnet size based upon need.  
Attempted to hold with just the magnets on the steel frame, this worked but not well enough for me so I ended up gluing it to the frame in the place I needed.
Printed with 50% infill in PLA at 230C with 60C heat bed.

title: Prusa Spool Holder and Support for 1kg Spools

description.text: Yet another spool holder for the Prusa, but this one has all the benefits/improvements I could think of. -Bent support design allows filament to line up directly above extruder and not rub on anything -My spools were damaged in shipping and the two sides were no longer attached. This inner and outer support holds the two halves together and allows for smooth rotation on the rod -Spiral slots so that the holder can simply be lifted on and off of the machine without needing to take apart your Prusa in any way. Extremely rigid to the frame when the spool is cantilevered on the end, but the spiral slots allow for easy removal without binding -Only vitamin is a leftover piece of threaded rod (and a 3mm Set Screw for added security locking in the threaded rod) -Weight/Filament savings optimized for strength -Spool inserts pivot smoothly on threaded rod with no bearings. If you look close you can see the inner pivot is extended up into the spool supports -Spool insert halves securely snap together. No bolt/hardware needed -Width is only constrained by length of threaded rod so you can have 1-3 spools on here -ENJOY! http://www.ev-guide.com/3d-printing-services
Print one of each Bent Spool Holders (Left and Right), then an inner and outer Spool Support for each spool that you have. http://www.ev-guide.com/3d-printing-services

title: Hinges for door for CTC, Creator, Wanhao Duplicator

description.text:
Just a simple pair of hinges for the front acrylic door on my CTC printer.  I wanted to try my hand at designing a few parts for my machine, and this was my first success.  
I made these to accommodate the .21" acrylic I used to enclose my printer.  The pins are easy enough to pop out in case I need to remove the door.

The hinge is in three parts: the bracket, the hinge itself, and the pin.  Designed to be mounted with #6 nuts and bolts.  
Definitely print the pins with a high infill percentage.  They'll be a tight fit through the bracket, so take care when inserting as not to snap them.

description.text:
Small vise that is printable, jaws are 2" wide and can open up to 1.5".  Use M4x60mm Pan Head Phillips from Lowe's and 2xM4 nuts, one in the back of the jaw to lock the machine screw and one in the spur wheel.  
This is a project for a class in school that I have made, I have not printed it yet but will be doing so soon.  Gap between jaws has a .5" radius so you hopefully don't have to bridge it.  
Note: This was drawn in inches.  
Edit:  Wheel was updated to have the extrusion on only one side, please place the extrusion at the back so when tightening the jaw, the forced is placed on this small extrusion so it should be easier to turn.  I realized that without a professional machine it would be near impossible to print a .010" thick extrusion on the bottom side.  
Edit 2: Printed it today and everything worked perfectly with the new wheel file.  
Edit 3 (11/25/2013): Rotated base and block, all parts should now be printable in current configuration.

Print all three pieces, place jaw in the vise first then run bolt through the hole in the front of the base block through a nut in the jaw.  Place nut in spur wheel and slide up into base before tightening the bolt into the jaw.

title: i3V Z end stop replacement for micro adjustment, MakerFarm

Oct 15,2014: Newer Simple Z Endstop http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:501806 The new i3V 10" from MakerFarm had a terrible set up for the Z end stop. I wanted to make something I could micro adjust.
Hardware needed:
M5 T Nut

description.text:
I made everything fit onto a 20x20cm plate and made the base a bit smaller, so that I could order it from Seeedstudio's laser cutting service. Also, there was room for a couple of extra grippers.
Version V0.4.1 (the files as called XXXX2.XXX) has the following changes:

description.text:
A 2-part bobbin. 15 mm long (inside) and 21 mm long (outside). Diameter about 16 mm.  
Designed to take a 5 mm diameter ferrite rod. It turns out the transformer I wound on this was nowhere near as good as I wanted (probably due to the incomplete magnetic path) but it may be useful to someone anyway!

Prints as 2 parts with no support. 0.4 mm nozzle, 0.2 mm layers. Once printed, the top part of the bobbin is superglued to the bottom (superglue sticks PLA very well). Note the taper directions to match up the top of the bobbin with the main section. I found that the fit was perfect with my print settings (probably 80% infill but can't remember!).

Powerful customizer that makes unique rings, bracelets, crowns, or other round things you imagine. WARNING: due to the large number of calculations, the customizer may take a long time to update after making changes (maybe up to minute in extreme cases). UPDATE 2013/03/06
I tweaked the code a little and the STL's should generate roughly 2-3X faster. Yay

Open the customizer and have fun! See remixes for some settings to start with. Hints and Tips:

  • Try to minimize the number of segments and fragments per segment to reduce stl generation time. I'm not sure how much the servers can handle before they give up on generating the stl.

  • If you increase the number of whole periods, you'll want to increase the number of segments to keep the rails looking smooth.

  • The mirror reinforced setting gives the model a 'braided' instead of a spiral look.

  • Don't decrease the rail diameter too much or your printer won't be able to print your part, even if it generates supports.

  • The solid ring setting will fill the model with a solid ring to make it much easier to print.

comments.text: For those of you who have cool custom things that are hard to print yourself, I would recommend taking your .stl over to http://shapeways.comshapeways.com
comments.author: nac007

comments.text: I apologize in advance for the long wait time for STL generation of customized models. The code generates a rail made of hundreds of cylinders that have a hull applied to neighboring pairs, and then applies a union to the entire thing. Everything else I've tried is more inefficient, but maybe somebody knows a better way?

Turn your 3d printer in a beautiful 2d sketcher.
With this support you can draw with pen or pencil (not recomended) on sheet in a very precise way!
I hope you like

What do you need:
2x M3 nut
1x M4x20 screw with flat head
1x M4 wing nut

In order to do correct gcode to draw, instead print in 3d, I perform these steps:
1) Select the silhouette I'm interested in and import it in Illustrator
2) Auto tracing the edge and export in DWG
ALTERNATIVE: could be to do this step manually, tracing the contours in autocad or in a vector software you like/have.
3) Import in solidworks DWG and set a very thin thickness (< 0.2mm) and export the STL
ALTERNATIVE: you can do this directly in autocad
4) import STL in slic3r (i'm using slic3r but you can do in the software you like) taking care of the following settings:
  • Set a Z lift of 1.5mm at least
  • Set nozzle diameter to 0.2mm (this improve accuracy)
  • Disable top/bottom solid layers
  • Set the layer height to 0.2mm (equal to nozzle diam.)
  • Set seam position to "nearest"
  • Best and beautiful infill is IMHO rectilinear, the percentage is of your choice. Do some tests ;)
  • Set at the end of Gcode a lift >2mm (G91 ; G1 Z3 ;) before any movement
  • Speeds are the same for infill and perimeters (i'm using 40mm/s)
  • Disable skirts
  • Use low temperature (i'm using 40°C) just to deceive printer, because you cannot unplug the entire block of extrusion and its sensors, not worth the operation of the printer.
5) Place on the printing bed a thick sheet, latex or a dozen stacked sheets, and above the sheet you want to use to "draw"
6) Make sure to REMOVE filament from extruder and feeder
7) Set the Z zero point 0.8mm - 1mm below the shet level. More than this height will be high, more the trait will be pronounced
8) PRINT!
I don't suggest to use pencil because because in some decimetre the tip is consumed.
If the pen doesn't write, before printing it is best to rub a piece of paper under the tip to spin the ball and get out the ink.
There're two STLs, one is for hexagonal staedler pen/pencil and the other one is for nibs or round pen.
ENJOY!

A flat SD card holder that clips onto the walls of your Rep2 without taking up much space.
Designed to be quick to print, secure, easy to access and to maximize the visibility of the SD card label.
Can attach anywhere on the outside of the Rep2, even upside down and it'll grip on. SD cards also gently wedge in at the bottom so cards won't fall out either.
Updated version has a slight bend to the back lip to help grip better.

Designed to be printed at 0.2mm. Walls are close enough together that you don't need infill.
Images shown were printed with 1 shell, 0 infill, 0.2mm, sliced in MakerWare with Skeinforge. Prints in about 25 min with listed settings and default speeds. I suggest printing with clear or translucent PLA. Prints with 2 small flat circular supports to prevent curling, which are easy to rip off.

title: Dial Indicator Mount for Shapeoko 2 Rotary Tool Holder

description.text:
Just a Dial Indicator Mount I made for the Shapeoko 2 Rotary Tool Holder. Sized for a AccuRemote Digital Indicator: http://amzn.to/1qJbTZM
Based this off of lordmundi's Pen Holder, however the .SKP file included in his thing was a bit of a mess (looked like a STL converted to SKP). So I created this .SKP from scratch.
Washed my .STL through the Netfabb cloud service for good measure.
Printed in ABS, .2mm layer height, .25% infill, 4 perimeters, solid infill every 15 layers (I just like this), and a 5mm brim just for safety. Holes are sized for M5 and M3 screws.

Parametric version of mendel microswitch endstop holder, with most things changeable.

Print out the STL file, attach to your axles with an M3 bolt, attach to your microswitches with screws, and hope that your printer will work better now you're not using tape. If needed, change the parameters of the SCAD file and recompile. Here are the current settings in SCAD file: bw = 5; // bracket width
bh = 10; // bracket height
cl = 15; // clamp length
ad = 8; // axle diameter
hd = 3; // bolt hole diameter
nd = 6; // bolt nut diameter
mhd = 2.5; // microswitch hole diameter
ai = 0.75; // axle inset for clamp
xw = 0.4; // extrude width
mhs = 9.5; // microswitch hole separation
bl = cl + ad / 2 + (bw - ai) + hd * 3 + mhs; // bracket length I didn't add a nut capture ala thing:30085, because I'm still trying to print simple things and I don't yet trust my printer's ability to print overhangs.

title: Fishing rod REEL  -  MOULINET de canne a peche

description.text:
UPDATE 2015/02/03
I posted the latest version of my trout reel.
For the pawl kind system, I used two magnets (Ø8mm), acting in opposition. This choice replaces the use of springs. There are two positions.
I haven't tried it yet "for real", but I'm really looking forward the trout fishing opening !!
Video : http://youtu.be/8kbUqUVR8Oo MISE A JOUR
J'ai mis en ligne la dernière version de mon moulinet.
Pour le système type "cliquet", j'ai utilisé 2 aimants (Ø8mm) qui agissent en opposition. Ce choix remplace l'utilisation de ressorts. Il y a deux positions.
Je ne l'ai pas encore essayé "en vrai", vivement l'ouverture de la pêche à la truite !!

UPDATE 2014/09/30
I will try to add a pawl kind system.
Be free to tell me what you are thinking of that system ? MISE A JOUR
J'ai ajouté un système type "cliquet".
Si vous avez des idées/remarques, n'hésitez pas !

Hi,
I started the designing of a reel for my fishing rod.
This reel is for the trout fishing with the technique called "pêche aux appats naturels" ou "pêche au toc" in french (don't have the translation for that).
To be simple, this technique use a reel like a simple line reserve.
The line has to be really thin (0.20mm and less). That's why I added the red chenille yarn (like on the old french reels), to avoid the line go out of the reel (that could happen). Here a link of a french company of reels for trout fishing : http://www.peerless-bam.fr/moulinets_de_riviere/page_ritma72d.htm I haven't finished the design yet, but I hope you will try to help me to finish it and/or improve it.
The part where I'm stucked is the system for stop the reel spinning. I need a SIMPLE system with two position :
  • one position that free everything, I can go on the two directions freely (to adjust the lenght of the line before send it to the water)
  • one position that block the reel in one direction but not the other (that will allow me to get the trout that will bite close to me, and not allow it to go far).
    • And of course I have to add a whole to get the wire our the reel. Sorry for my bad english, hope you will enjoy my reel :-) Salut,
    J'ai commencé à designer ce moulinet pour la pêche au toc (ou pêche aux appâts naturels).
    Pour cette technique de pèche, le moulinet ne sert que de réservoir à fil, et accessoirement ramener le poisson si il a mordu.
    Comme le fil doit rester assez fin, il n'est pas rare qu'il sorte du moulinet si les spires ne sont pas tendues. C'est pourquoi j'ai ajouté ces fils chenilles rouges (ça empêche le fil de dérailler). C'est ce qui était utilisé sur mon vieux Ritma et qui fonctionnait très bien. Pour info, voici le lien d'un très célèbre fabriquant Fr de moulinet pour pêche au toc : http://www.peerless-bam.fr/moulinets_de_riviere/page_ritma72d.htm Je n'ai pas fini le moulinet, j'espère que vous pourrez m'aider à le finir/amélioré.
    Je suis bloqué pour trouver un système SIMPLE d'anti-retour. Il me faut 2 positions :
  • une position où rien n'est freiné, ça tourne tout seul (ça me servira à dévider du fil à la demande)
  • une position où il est impossible de dévider du fil (quand la truite mord), mais que je puisse aller dans l'autre sens pour ramener le poisson.
    • Il me reste aussi à ajouter le trou de sortie du fil, mais ça ne devrait pas être compliqué à dessiner. Bon j'espère que ça vous plaira, j'attends vos idées avec impatience :-)

For use on the XL20 and XL21 Xlerator Wheel Stands. The shifter is a little less than 12mm holes for those rods that come with the wheel, and the bolts are 10mm that mount it to the shifter adapter. These will take up the slack and make the shifter easier to get tight. Also the washers on the bushings will protect the shifter from the turning bolts. Race on!
Print without raft or support. Should fit right in shifter body without any filing or drilling

I bought some electric candles from World Market (no worries about fires), and I wanted to be able to put them on the top of the shaker headboard of our bed... to create a nice romantic mood.  But who wants to be laying there with the possibility of a candle falling and hitting you on the head?  
I designed this candle holder which fits over the top edge of the headboard and has an inset for the candle. I built in the supports and I am using small helper disks on the corners.  
There is a small notch at the bottom of one edge. This is to help pry the print off the build platform with something like a screwdriver. Put the notch side of your candle holder facing the wall.   
It works great!  
I made this on a Makerbot Replicator 2.

If printing in PLA put down wide blue painters tape on print bed.
Sand surface of painters tape.
Clean painters tape with alcohol in case any oils from your fingers got on the surface.
Does not need you to add supports since they are part of the model.
Once the helper disks are finished printing, pick change filament option (to get the print-head out of the way). Make sure to not touch the print head since it will be hot!
Put thin blue painters tape over the helper disks across the print bed to help them stay put.
Resume the print unit done.
Remove helper disks and built-in supports.
Simple and useful tweezers.
Additional holders you can glue to some surface to create place where you always left tweezers.
For fun.

OpenSCAD module library for a gaming tile system on a square grid. I mostly play Pathfinder and D&D, so I need a 1" grid. Since everyone on Thingiverse seems to be metric, and 1" works out to 25.4mm, the pattern set is intended to produce 26mm grid spaces. Walls themselves are 4mm thick, and set between grid spaces, not within the grid square. This is really the only way to have real physical walls for something like D&D, unless you want walls to consume entire squares. Pattern set consists of "walls" and "posts". Posts are designed to sit at the ends of walls and hold them together, giving them some rigidity. I couldn't see how to have walls connect directly with each other and still keep the number of unique parts very low. The wall module has recesses intended to receive the post module, and a protrusion on the bottom intended to be receives by a plate module. The pocket on the top is not intended to receive another wall module, but instead a thin protrusion extending from the bottom of the plates; in this way, you can construct a building or dungeon with multiple levels. The plate module holds sockets for the wall module's bottom protrusions. They also hold smaller protrusions underneath, allowing them to be set on top of erect walls, as well as easily and loosely stacked upon one another, for storage. Plates do not (and should not) strongly plug into anything they're set upon; this should allow them to be easily lifted off of whatever they're set on without accidentally pulling on or dismantling anything underneath. The plates also have round indentations on them. These are intended to allow the placement of furniture-style items. There are only a few remaining things to do before I consider this Thing complete:
  • Code cleanup. Walls, posts, plates, examples, etc. should each be in a separate file.
  • Plates should have a side-ways interlocking mechanism to allow you to build larger plates out of already-printed smaller plates.
  • Walls need to support facades. This will be done with hook-shaped recesses, allowing facade tiles to be easily set and removed.
  • There may need to be a "buttress" wall module, for post stability on corners. I'll design it. If it proves to be unnecessary, well, great.
  • Plates may get round bumps added to their undersides. These will settle into the round recesses on top, to make plate stack alignment easy.
  • After the above are done, play testing is in order, to verify that the interfaces all work together the way I intended, and to find any design weaknesses that need to be corrected.
    • After those are done, I think this Thing will be reasonably complete; it will largely be a set of libraries defining basic components. Things like large plates, long walls, windows and roof components can all be designed and uploaded as separate Things; the interfaces will have been designed, and anything that follows them should work fine. Future Things will include:
  • Facades that support attaching miniatures to walls, so that climbing miniatures can be placed visually where they're thought to be.
  • Rooftop modules.
  • Doors
  • Windows
  • Long walls
  • Large plates
  • Tall walls.
    • (At least some of these will be constructed as parametric libraries. I.e. "make me a wall this many tiles long and this many floors high...")

I haven't tried printing this yet. I don't have a printer, though there's a couple at the local makerspace. I don't care to waste plastic, so I want to get the design as close to end goals as possible first. When you open the file, you'll see two variables near the top, named BASEA and BASEB. These control the scale of the rest of the library. You should be able to scale the library up for, e.g. 28mm/Heroic scale. Or scale it down to something like 16mm (I'm guessing here) for Lego(tm) creatures. BASEA controls the size of the squares themselves. BASEB controls the thickness of the walls and the size of all of the component interfaces. One more thing: I put the whole thing up on Github, so I could have it under proper version control. (Why doesn't Thingiverse do something like that?) https://github.com/mikemol/gridwall

This key is my first 3D object made with openscad. I chose this for two reasons.
It's a nice object to learn how to work with openscad.
And more important: I think every geek, hacker, technician want to have this tool in their toolbox!!!! This key fits on a lot of cool things.
I tested it with trafic lights and street lights
but this will also work for
For control cabinets, shut-off systems in gas, water and electricity supplies
For technical installations in buildings like air-conditioning and ventilation systems, shut-off valves, mains switchboards etc. please post your results in the comments ;)

This is just a replica of the key you see in the picture which is made in metal.
If you want to print it in plastic (which i did) it may be not strong enough so you can size the diameter of the cylinders up (openscad) so you'll get a heavy duty model.
